Description: Mould-made pottery oil-lamp (copying wheel-made types) with a double-convex body, an inward-sloping rim defined by a groove, a solid lug on the left side, a short tapering flat-topped nozzle with a rounded end, and a ring-base with a flat boss in the centre. Brown Nile silt with black and white inclusions.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by Birmingham City Museum and Art Gallery. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Crude Egyptian copy of Athenian type (Howland 1958, Type 25 and 32), or Rhodian predecessors (Bailey 1975, 250). 3rd to 2nd century BC parallel from Alexandria (Mlynarczyk 1998, 330, Fig.1b). Alexandrian types, including parallels from Athribis are dated to the late 3rd to mid 2nd century BC (Mlynarczyk 1997, 18-20, Type A.a.2, Fig. 6). Late 3rd to early 2nd century BC parallels from Tell Atrib (Młynarczyk 2012, type TA 11.1). Mlynarczyk, J. 1997. Alexandrian and Alexandria-influenced mould-made lamps of the Hellenistic period. BAR International Series 677. Mlynarczyk, J. 1998. Terracotta mould-made lamps in Alexandria (Hellenistic to Late Roman period), in Empereur, J-Y. (ed.), Commerce et Artisant dans l’Alexandrie Hellénistique et Romaine, Paris, 327-52. Młynarczyk, J. 2012. Tell Atrib 1985-1995. Vol. 3: Terracotta oil lamps. Varsovie: Éditions Neriton. Howland, R.H. 1958. The Athenian Agora, IV, Greek lamps and their survivals, Princeton.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (KD.006) (Phase 3)
